prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
In Band 6, we will observe the spectral lines of CCH. The intensity of CCH (N=3-2, J=5/2-3/2, F=3-2) line is calculated from that of CCH (N=4-3) lines to be 450 mJy/(0."7 x 0."45 beam) with velocity resolution of 0.14 km/s. Considering that the structure is unresolved or marginally resolved toward the disk in the Cycle 0 observation, the expected intensity with the 0."23 beam is 76 mJy/beam or higher. With the rms noise of 7.6 mJy/beam, we will be able to obtain velocity channel maps with a reasonable S/N ratio of 10 or higher. In addition to CCH, we utilize the c-C3H2 emission to confirm the velocity structure seen in CCH. In Band 7, we will observe the spectral lines of H2CO (515-414 and 505-404). The intensity of H2CO (515-414) line is 450 mJy/(0."6 x 0."44 beam) with velocity resolution of 0.1 km/s in the Cycle 0 observation. Considering that the structure of the disk is unresolved in the Cycle 0 observation, the expected intensity with the 0."16 beam is 73 mJy/beam or higher. With the rms noise of 7.3 mJy/beam, we will be able to obtain velocity channel maps with a reasonable S/N ratio of 10 or higher. Time estimation tells us the total observing time of 2.92 hours (0.97+1.95 hours).
We include the 34SO (J_N=5_6-4_5) and SO (J_N=2_3-3_2) lines to derive the optical depth of SO and the physical condition accurately. The latter line has a lower upper state energy than the other lines, and hence, it is useful to constrain the physical conditions of the emitting region. Furthermore, we also simultaneously observe SiO, HNCO, SO2, and 34SO2 to learn the strength of the shock. HC3N, C3H+, and c-C3H2 are also included as bonus lines. If detected at this high spatial resolution, we can compare the behavior of the CnHm species with that of the cyanopolyyne. H2CO is one of the standard molecules whose distribution can be compared with those of above molecular species. NH2CHO is the completely bonus line (the velocity resolution can be reduced by a factor of 2 to reduce the data rate), but it is interesting to see whether such a complex species is contained in the disk forming region or not. Thus, we need large "data rate" which exceeds the "policy" value of 12 MB/s.

In Band 6, we will observe the spectral lines of CCH. The intensity of CCH (N=3-2, J=5/2-3/2, F=3-2) line is calculated from that of CCH (N=4-3) lines to be 450 mJy/(0."7 x 0."45 beam) with velocity resolution of 0.14 km/s. Considering that the structure is unresolved or marginally resolved toward the disk in the Cycle 0 observation, the expected intensity with the 0."23 beam is 76 mJy/beam or higher. With the rms noise of 7.6 mJy/beam, we will be able to obtain velocity channel maps with a reasonable S/N ratio of 10 or higher. In addition to CCH, we utilize the c-C3H2 emission to confirm the velocity structure seen in CCH. In Band 7, we will observe the spectral lines of H2CO (515-414 and 505-404). The intensity of H2CO (515-414) line is 450 mJy/(0."6 x 0."44 beam) with velocity resolution of 0.1 km/s in the Cycle 0 observation. Considering that the structure of the disk is unresolved in the Cycle 0 observation, the expected intensity with the 0."16 beam is 73 mJy/beam or higher. With the rms noise of 7.3 mJy/beam, we will be able to obtain velocity channel maps with a reasonable S/N ratio of 10 or higher. Time estimation tells us the total observing time of 2.92 hours (0.97+1.95 hours).
H2CO lines are included as standard molecular lines to study the disk/envelope structure. By using the K=0, 1, and 2 lines, the gas kinematic temperature and the H2 density are evaluated. In our Cycle 0 proposal, the CH3OH lines are marginally detected with very compact distribution around the protostar. It is very important to confirm it with higher resolution observations to explore how effectively hot corino activity is seen in the WCCC source, IRAS 15398-3359. The c-C3H2 lines are detected in our Cycle 0 observation, and if it is detected at high angular resolution, we can derive the temperature and density in the innermost part of the infalling rotating envelope in combination with the lines of c-C3H2 included in the Band 6 setting. We include SO2 to learn the strength of the shock around the centrifugal barrier. The HC3N, DCN, and 15NNH+ lines are bonus lines, but they are useful to characterize the chemical conditions of the disk/envelope. Thus, we need large "data rate" which exceeds the "policy" value of 12 MB/s.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: In star-formation studies, an important target is to understand when and how the rotationally supported disk is formed around the protostar. In order to address this question, we recently conducted the ALMA observations of the CCH (N=4-3) and H2CO (515-414 etc.) lines in Band 7 toward the low-mass Class 0 protostar IRAS 15398-3359 at a resolution of 0."5. We detected a beautiful outflow feature as well as a flattened envelope around the protostar. From the analysis of the outflow structure, the inclination angle of the envelope is estimated to be 10 degree (i.e. almost edge-on). Then, the velocity structure of the envelope is analyzed, and the mass of the protostar is roughly estimated to be as low as 0.02 Msun. Furthermore, the H2CO emission shows a sign of a Keplerian disk. These results will be an important clue to understanding the initial stage of disk formation processes, if confirmed. We here propose to observe the CCH (N=3-2) and H2CO (515-414 etc.) lines in the Band 6 and Band 7 at the resolution of 0."23 and 0."16, respectively. This observation will provide us with a deep insight into the initial stage of disk formation in Class 0 protostars.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Physics, University of Tokyo

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: School of Science, The University of Tokyo
Graduate School of Science, The University of Tokyo
Mizusawa VERA Observatory, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
